journal-title-group.journal-title: The Journal of Financial and Quantitative Analysis

publisher.publisher-name: University of Washington Graduate School of Business Administration

title-group.article-title: Can Omitted Risk Factors Explain the January Effect? A Stochastic Dominance Approach

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 1993 School of Business Administration, University of Washington

abstract.p: This paper provides a direct test of the hypothesis that large January returns can be attributed to omitted risk factors. Data from 1926-1991 show that the January return in the smallest decile of NYSE firms dominates the January returns for all other deciles by the first-order stochastic dominance. Similarly, January returns in all deciles (with the exception of ninth and tenth deciles) dominate non-January returns by first-, second-, or third-order stochastic dominance. The presence of stochastic dominance by January returns suggests that the omitted risk factors are not likely to explain the January effect.
